questions.text: What is not a feature of myasthenia gravis among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Areflexia

 

  •  Reflexes are preserved in myasthenia gravis; areflexia suggests peripheral neuropathy or other motor neuron disorders.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Decremental response on RNS: Seen in MG due to defective neuromuscular transmission and fatigability.


Option C. Normal pupillary reflex: Pupils remain unaffected in MG, unlike in some other neuromuscular disorders.


Option D. Improvement with Inj. Edrophonium: Basis of the Tensilon test, a diagnostic feature of MG.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT is shown below. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous thrombolysis

 

  •  The patient has acute ischemic stroke (left-sided facial weakness, <4.5 hours, CT shows no bleed). IV thrombolysis is the treatment of choice if no contraindications.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. CT angiogram: Useful for large vessel occlusion planning (thrombectomy) but not the immediate next step if thrombolysis window is open.


Option B. Start on aspirin + clopidogrel: Antiplatelet therapy is started if outside the thrombolysis window or after thrombolysis, not the immediate first step.


Option D. IV Labetalol: Used for BP control if systolic >185 or diastolic >110 mmHg before thrombolysis; here, BP is 160/100, so not needed now.

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autonomic dysfunction

 

  •  Autonomic dysfunction (orthostatic hypotension, constipation, urinary problems) can occur in Lewy body dementia but it is not a core diagnostic feature.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Fluctuating cognition: One of the hallmark core features, with episodes of confusion alternating with lucidity.


Option B. Rigidity and pill-rolling tremors: Parkinsonism is a core feature of Lewy body dementia.


Option C. Visual hallucinations: Well-formed, recurrent visual hallucinations are a key diagnostic criterion.

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in all these conditions, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood pressure of more than 185/110 mm Hg

 

  •  Severe uncontrolled hypertension is a contraindication to IV thrombolysis; BP must be reduced below 185/110 mmHg before proceeding.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. ASPECTS score >7: Indicates limited infarct core; patients are good candidates for thrombolysis.

 

Option C. Ischemic stroke within 2 hours: Well within the 4.5-hour therapeutic window, making the patient eligible.


Option D. Onset of symptoms <4 hours: Also within the approved thrombolysis window, hence acceptable.

choices.text: Anterior spinal artery injury at T8

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the back. Neurological examination demonstrates the absence of motor activity in all muscle groups of the right lower extremity as well as decreased muscle tone. Left leg motor function is normal. Right patellar reflex, Achilles reflex, and Babinski sign are absent. There is loss of light touch and proprioception below the right costal margin. Pinprick sensation is absent below the level of umbilicus on the left side. Which of the following is the most likely location of this patient's injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right spinal hemisection at T8

 

  • This is a classic presentation of Brown-Séquard syndrome (hemisection of spinal cord) → ipsilateral motor weakness + loss of proprioception/vibration, and contralateral loss of pain/temperature below the lesion.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with four days of progressive, bilateral, lower extremity weakness and dysesthesia. The patient denies any history of trauma, but states that he stayed home from work last week because of fever accompanied by diarrhea. Neurologic examination demonstrates the absence of reflexes in the lower extremities with no cranial nerve deficits. What is the best therapy for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmapheresis 

 

  •  The patient has Guillain-Barré syndrome (post-infectious, ascending weakness, areflexia). Plasmapheresis (or IVIG) is the mainstay of treatment.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids: Not effective in GBS; they do not improve outcomes.They are infact contra indicated in GB syndrome.


Option C. Acetaminophen: Symptomatic drug for fever/pain; has no role in treating GBS.


Option D. Radiation therapy: No role in autoimmune demyelinating peripheral neuropathies like GBS.

questions.text: 34-year-old man is evaluated in the clinic due to difficulty walking over the past 2 weeks. His symptoms have resulted in several recent falls. The physician asks him to stand with his feet close together, arms to the sides, and eyes closed. This maneuver most likely tests for abnormalities in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proprioception

 

  • The described maneuver is the Romberg test, which evaluates dorsal column function (position sense). Worsening sway with eyes closed indicates impaired proprioception.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Cortical sensory integration: Tested by stereognosis, graphesthesia, and two-point discrimination (parietal cortex), not by Romberg.


Option B. Gait: Assessed by observing walking patterns (e.g., tandem gait), not by standing feet together with eyes closed.


Option C. Motor coordination: Cerebellar coordination is checked with finger-to-nose or heel-to-shin.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the OPD for treatment of anxiety that has worsened over the past year. She says, "My anxiety just comes out of the blue; one way or another, I'm anxious all the time.  An anxiety disorder is diagnosed, and fluoxetine is prescribed. The patient's anxiety begins to improve over the next 4-6 weeks. The physician explains that the medication inhibits the reuptake of a neurotransmitter released by a specific set of neurons. These neurons are likely part of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Raphe nuclei

 

  • Fluoxetine is an SSRI that increases serotonin levels. Serotonin is primarily produced by the raphe nuclei in the brainstem.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Caudate nucleus: Part of the basal ganglia involved in motor control and habit learning, not serotonin production.


Option B. Locus ceruleus: Major site of norepinephrine synthesis, associated with arousal and stress response.


Option C. Nucleus basalis of Meynert: Source of acetylcholine, implicated in memory and cognition, especially in Alzheimer’s disease.

questions.text: All of the factors would suggest a higher risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duration of symptoms 5 mins

 

  • In ABCD2 scoring, TIA duration <10 minutes does not add any points, so it does not increase stroke risk.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Age 65 years: Age ≥60 years gives 1 point, increasing risk.


Option C. BP 140/90 mmHg: Hypertension at presentation gives 1 point.


Option D. Diabetes: Presence of diabetes adds 1 point, raising stroke risk.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, diplopia, hoarseness, dysphagia and left Horner's syndrome associated with numbness of the left face and right-side limbs. Which artery is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery 

 

  •  The findings describe Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome, classically caused by PICA infarction → ipsilateral Horner’s, facial sensory loss, contralateral body sensory loss, and bulbar symptoms.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option B. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA): Causes lateral pontine syndrome (facial paralysis, hearing loss, vertigo), not the classic Wallenberg picture.


Option C. Superior cerebellar artery: Infarction produces ipsilateral ataxia and cerebellar signs, not bulbar cranial nerve involvement.


Option D. Basilar artery: Large infarcts here cause “locked-in” syndrome with quadriplegia, not the lateral medullary syndrome described.

questions.text: 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to seizures. He has had 2 days of worsening fever, headache, and vomiting. Physical examination shows signs of meningeal irritation. The patient rapidly becomes comatose and dies 48 hours later despite aggressive medical care. Autopsy examination shows congested leptomeninges with fibrinopurulent exudate. Microscopy reveals numerous ameba in the exudate and brain  tissue. Which of the following is the most likely portal of entry of this pathogen into the CNS?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E

 

The most likely portal of entry of the pathogen in this scenario is the cribriform plate (E), corresponding to the site labeled "E" in the image, which is where Naegleria fowleri (an ameba causing primary amebic meningoencephalitis) typically enters the CNS via the olfactory nerve after inhalation of contaminated water.

 

Case Analysis

 

  • The patient presents with rapidly progressing meningoencephalitis leading to death, and autopsy reveals amebae in the brain tissue, most consistent with Naegleria fowleri infection.
  • The usual portal for this amoeba is via the nasal mucosa, entering through the cribriform plate to reach the CNS.

 

Brain Anatomy Identified

 

  • A: Brainstem
  • B: Basilar artery
  • C: Oculomotor nerve
  • D: Optic chiasma
  • E: Cribriform plate region (where the olfactory nerves pass through)

choices.text: Aorta - brachiocephalic artery - common carotid artery - external carotid artery
Aorta - brachiocephalic artery - common carotid artery - internal carotid artery
Aorta - common carotid artery - external carotid artery
Aorta - common carotid artery - internal carotid artery

questions.text: A 62-year-old, right-handed man is evaluated for an episode of left leg weakness that spontaneously resolved within 30 minutes of onset. The patient also has had transient vision loss in the right eye. Medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Evaluation reveals an atherosclerotic plaque in the extracranial portion of the supplying artery. During percutaneous stenting, the vascular catheter is inserted into the right common femoral artery and gradually advanced to the level of the aortic arch. Which of the following is the most likely path of the catheter before stenting of the culprit lesion can be performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aorta - brachiocephalic artery - common carotid artery - internal carotid artery

 

  • From a right common femoral arterial access the catheter is advanced up the aorta into the brachiocephalic (innominate) artery, which gives rise to the right common carotid; the catheter is then passed into the internal carotid to reach the extracranial carotid lesion supplying the eye/brain.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Aorta - brachiocephalic artery - common carotid artery - external carotid artery: The external carotid supplies face/neck structures, not the retinal/ intracranial circulation responsible for amaurosis fugax/stroke, so this would not reach the culprit lesion.


Option C. Aorta - common carotid artery - external carotid artery: On the right side the common carotid does not arise directly from the aorta (it comes from the brachiocephalic); also this ends in the external carotid, which is not the target.


Option D. Aorta - common carotid artery - internal carotid artery: The right common carotid arises from the brachiocephalic, not directly from the aorta, so this path is anatomically incorrect for a right-sided lesion.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcutaneous sumatriptan

 

  •  The treatment of choice for an acute cluster headache attack is rapid-acting therapy such as subcutaneous sumatriptan or high-flow oxygen. SC route works within minutes.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Oral sumatriptan: Too slow in onset; not effective for aborting cluster headaches which peak rapidly.


Option C. 100% oxygen at 6 L/minute: Oxygen is effective, but the correct flow is ≥12 L/min via non-rebreather mask; 6 L/min is insufficient.


Option D. Propranolol: Used for migraine prophylaxis, not for aborting acute cluster headache.

questions.text: A 38-year-old hospitalized woman is evaluated for new-onset confusion. The patient has a prolonged history of Crohn disease. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Abduction of the right eye is limited and elicits bilateral horizontal nystagmus. Motor strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal throughout. Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin testing are normal, but the gait is wide based. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's neurologic symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine deficiency

 

  • The triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia (abducens palsy with nystagmus), and ataxia is classic for Wernicke encephalopathy, caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often seen in malnutrition or malabsorption (e.g., Crohn’s disease).

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency : Causes subacute combined degeneration with peripheral neuropathy, loss of vibration/position sense, and spastic paresis, not acute ophthalmoplegia with confusion.


Option C. Folate deficiency: Leads to megaloblastic anaemia but does not cause neurologic syndromes like ophthalmoplegia or ataxia.


Option D. Cerebellar dysfunction: Explains ataxia but not the confusion and oculomotor palsy seen here.

choices.text: Blockade of presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels
Blockade of presynaptic voltage-gated sodium channels
Inhibition of vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to recurrent, generalized tonic-clonic seizures over the past 24 hours. He takes no medications and has no family history of epilepsy. The patient's temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 10/min. During the examination, the patient suddenly develops sustained, generalized tonic-clonic convulsions without fully regaining consciousness between episodes. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of the most appropriate initial therapy for his seizures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enhanced postsynaptic chloride influx

 

  • The initial therapy for ongoing generalized tonic–clonic seizures/status epilepticus in a child is a benzodiazepine (eg, IV lorazepam or IM midazolam), which potentiates GABA-A receptors

questions.text: 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her son after he found her acting strangely. She was asking to open the window blinds, even though the blinds were already open and was bumping into objects when walking around her home. The patient insists that her vision is fine and came to the hospital upon her son’s insistence. Bilateral direct and consensual pupillary reflexes are normal. On confrontation visual field testing, she reports the wrong number of fingers in all visual quadrants. The patient indicates the wrong direction when asked to point to the door and gives an incorrect visual description when asked to describe the physician. This patient most likely has an infarction involving the brain regions supplied by which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior cerebral artery

 

  •  This is classic cortical blindness with anosognosia (Anton syndrome) from bilateral occipital lobe infarcts in the PCA territory — pupils and anterior visual pathways are intact, but cortical visual processing is lost.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery: Causes contralateral leg-predominant motor/sensory deficits and frontal–executive dysfunction, not isolated cortical visual loss.


Option B. Basilar artery: Produces brainstem and cerebellar signs (locked-in syndrome, cranial nerve deficits), not isolated occipital cortical blindness.


Option C. Ophthalmic artery: Affects the eye/retina (monocular visual loss or retinal ischemia), and would usually alter pupillary/ocular findings rather than cause bilateral cortical blindness.

choices.text: 10% of the normal population can have epileptiform discharges.
Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.
Doing EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 10% of the normal population can have epileptiform discharges.

 

  •  Only about 1% of healthy individuals may show epileptiform discharges; 10% is an overestimation, hence incorrect.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option B. Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy: True, though sometimes challenging due to deep seizure foci, scalp EEG can still provide useful localization.


Option C. Doing EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures: Correct, seizures are primarily a clinical diagnosis; EEG supports but is not always required.


Option D. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves: True, diffuse slowing and triphasic waves can be seen in metabolic and infectious encephalopathies like PML.

questions.text: 34-year-old woman with sleep problems comes to the OPD. Over the last year, she has had increasing difficulty falling asleep at night and is exhausted during the day. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. She has a family history of heart disease and depression. The patient has failed a number of nonpharmacological approaches, including cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia. She requests pharmacologic treatment and is prescribed a short course of zolpidem. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GABA receptor agonism

 

  •  Zolpidem is a non-benzodiazepine hypnotic (“Z-drug”) that selectively binds the GABA-A receptor at the benzodiazepine site, enhancing chloride influx and promoting sleep.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine receptor antagonism: Mechanism of antipsychotics, not hypnotics.


Option C. Histamine receptor antagonism: Seen with sedating antihistamines (eg, diphenhydramine, doxylamine), not zolpidem.


Option D. Melatonin receptor agonism: Mechanism of drugs like ramelteon, not zolpidem.

choices.text: Fasciculation at the level of lesion

questions.text: Which of the following does not help in the localization of lesions in the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contralateral hemiplegia

 

  •  Spinal cord lesions typically produce ipsilateral motor weakness below the lesion; contralateral hemiplegia is usually of cerebral/brainstem origin, not spinal.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option B. Fasciculation at the level of lesion: Suggests lower motor neuron involvement at the level of the cord lesion.


Option C. Babinski positive: Indicates upper motor neuron involvement below the lesion, localizing to the spinal cord.


Option D. Bladder involvement: Suggests cord-level pathology (especially above the sacral segments), useful in localization.

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever, neck rigidity and altered sensorium. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? 

 

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h
  2. Start injection ceftriaxone
  3. Fundoscopy
  4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, 2

 

  •  In suspected meningitis, stabilize the patient first with IV access/fluids → check for raised ICP by fundoscopy → do a guarded lumbar puncture if no papilledema → then start antibiotics (ceftriaxone).

 

Opter Options:.

 

Option A. 1, 2, 4, 3: Antibiotics before fundoscopy & LP skips the essential check for papilledema/raised ICP.


Option B. 1, 4, 3, 2: LP before fundoscopy risks herniation if ICP is elevated.


Option C. 4, 3, 2, 1: Starts with LP without stabilization or fundoscopy, unsafe approach.

questions.text: A highly agitated 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family because he is unable to effectively communicate. He speaks clearly and with conviction but his sentences are incomprehensible. He does not appear to understand the doctor's questions, does not follow oral or written instructions, and cannot repeat simple phrases. Branch occlusion of which of the following arteries is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left Middle cerebral artery-inferior division

 

  •  The patient has Wernicke’s aphasia (fluent but nonsensical speech, impaired comprehension, inability to repeat). This localizes to the posterior superior temporal gyrus in the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, supplied by the inferior division of the left MCA.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Right MCA – superior division: Would affect motor cortex (contralateral face/arm weakness), not language in a right-handed person.


Option B. Right MCA – inferior division: Would not cause aphasia since the right hemisphere is usually non-dominant for language.


Option C. Left MCA – superior division: Causes Broca’s aphasia (nonfluent speech with good comprehension), not fluent but meaningless speech.

questions.text:
What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? 

 

  1. LMN lesion of trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

  •  Central cord lesions typically damage gray matter at the level of the lesion → LMN signs at that level (eg, trunk/upper limb weakness) and may also compress descending tracts → UMN signs in lower limbs. As the lesion progresses centrally, bladder & bowel involvement is common.

 

1 (LMN trunk + UMN lower limbs): Correct, due to segmental LMN loss and long tract UMN involvement.


3 (Bladder and bowel involvement): Correct, central cord compression can disrupt autonomic pathways.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

2 (UMN trunk + LMN lower limbs): Not seen; UMN signs don’t occur at the lesion level.

4 (Posterior tract involvement): Typically spared in central lesions until very advanced, so not a defining feature.

questions.text:
Which of the following types of headaches requires further evaluation? 

 

  1. Duration > 4 hours
  2. Thunderclap nature 
  3. Associated Low GCS 
  4. Associated Blurring of vision
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4

 

Red flag features in headaches that warrant urgent evaluation include:

 

2. Thunderclap headache → sudden, severe onset, may suggest subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

3. Altered consciousness / low GCS → indicates raised intracranial pressure, hemorrhage, infection, or mass lesion.

 

4. Blurring of vision → could indicate raised ICP, papilledema, or secondary pathology.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

1. Duration > 4 hours → common in migraines, tension headaches, etc., but not by itself a red flag unless associated with other features.

choices.text: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture growing acid-fast bacilli
CSF PCR positive for herpes virus
Encapsulated yeasts on CSF India ink preparation
Reactive VDRL tests on CSF samples

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the OPD due to several weeks of difficulty walking and frequent falls. He also reports episodes of sharp, stabbing pain in his extremities. Deep-tendon reflexes are absent at the knee and ankle bilaterally. Proprioception and vibration sensation are reduced throughout the lower extremities. He has a wide-based gait and a positive Romberg sign. Which of the following diagnostic findings is most likely associated with this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reactive VDRL tests on CSF samples

 

  •  The patient has Tabes dorsalis (a late manifestation of neurosyphilis), characterized by lancinating pains, sensory ataxia, impaired vibration/proprioception, absent reflexes, and positive Romberg sign. CSF VDRL is diagnostic.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. CSF culture growing acid-fast bacilli: Suggests tuberculous meningitis, which presents with chronic headache, fever, cranial nerve palsies, not sensory ataxia and lightning pains.


Option B. CSF PCR positive for herpes virus: Indicates HSV encephalitis, presenting with fever, seizures, altered mental status, and temporal lobe involvement, not sensory neuropathy.


Option C. Encapsulated yeasts on CSF India ink preparation: Suggests cryptococcal meningitis (esp. in HIV patients), typically presenting with headache, fever, increased ICP, not Tabes dorsalis features.

choices.text: Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded
Inability to contract the right orbicularis oculi muscle
Vision defect affecting the left half of the visual field
Weakness of the right lateral rectus muscle

questions.text: 35-year-old woman with a history of migraines is evaluated due to a recent increase in headache frequency and severity. She has had no focal weakness, sensory loss, vision changes, or seizures. Neuroimaging reveals a small aneurysm arising from the segment of right internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus. If this patient's aneurysm continues to expand, which of the following findings is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weakness of the right lateral rectus muscle

 

  •  An aneurysm of the internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus can compress cranial nerves III, IV, V1, V2, and VI. The abducens nerve (CN VI) is most vulnerable due to its medial location, leading to impaired lateral rectus function (inability to abduct the eye).

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded: Caused by right hypoglossal (CN XII) palsy, not affected in the cavernous sinus.


Option B. Inability to contract the right orbicularis oculi muscle: Due to facial nerve (CN VII) palsy, which does not traverse the cavernous sinus.


Option C. Vision defect affecting the left half of the visual field: Suggests a lesion of the right optic tract; not caused by cavernous sinus pathology.

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the EEG shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

The EEG and polysomnogram pattern shown is characteristic of REM sleep.

Key Features in the Image

  • EEG: Shows low amplitude, mixed frequency waves—resembling awake state.
  • EOG (electro-oculogram): Shows rapid eye movements.
  • EMG (electromyogram): Shows muscle atonia (almost flat line).
  • ECG: Regular cardiac rhythm.
  • REM sleep is identified by rapid eye movements, low-amplitude, mixed-frequency EEG, and absent muscle tone (EMG atonia).

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. NREM1: Light sleep with theta waves.

 

Option B. NREM2: Sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Option C. NREM3: Deep sleep with delta waves.

 

Only REM sleep combines flattened EMG, rapid eye movements, and low-voltage EEG.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left dysdiadochokinesia

 

  • The MRI shows a lesion in the left cerebellar hemisphere.
  • The cerebellum is responsible for coordination of movement, and lesions here cause ipsilateral (same side) cerebellar signs due to double crossing of cerebellar pathways.
  • Dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid alternating movements) is a hallmark of cerebellar dysfunction and would occur on the left side due to a left cerebellar lesion.
  • Horner’s syndrome, hemiparesis, and hemisensory loss are not typical effects of isolated cerebellar lesions.

questions.text: 55-year-old woman is brought to the OPD by her husband for evaluation of strange behavior. She has been spending large amounts of money to buy expensive clothes and jewelry. She usually drinks 1 or 2 glasses of wine on weekends but lately has been drinking 2 or 3 glasses almost every day. This patient's condition is most likely due to abnormal accumulation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ubiquitinated TDP-43

 

  •  This presentation (late-life disinhibition, compulsive spending → behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia) is commonly associated with neuronal inclusions of ubiquitinated TDP-43.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Ataxin: Ataxin expansions cause spinocerebellar ataxias with progressive cerebellar dysfunction, not a behavioral frontal syndrome.
 

Option B. Beta-amyloid: Beta-amyloid plaques are characteristic of Alzheimer disease, which typically presents with memory loss rather than prominent early behavioral disinhibition.
 

Option C. Prions: Prion diseases (eg, CJD) cause rapidly progressive dementia with myoclonus and other features, not the slowly progressive behavioral variant seen here.

questions.text: The posture shown in image is seen in :
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper pons damage

 

The posture shown in the image is decerebrate rigidity/decerebrate posturing, characterized by extension and pronation of the arms, extended legs, and plantar flexed feet.

 

Key Association

 

  • Decerebrate posture indicates damage to the upper pons or lower midbrain, but classically it is seen in lesions affecting the upper pons

 

Decerebrate posture is a result of lesions below the red nucleus (in the upper pons or lower midbrain), leading to extensor posturing.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Upper pons hyperactivity: Hyperactivity is not the cause; rather, it’s upper pons damage.

 

Option B. Upper midbrain hyperactivity: Incorrect, hyperactivity isn’t relevant.

 

Option D. Upper midbrain damage: Would lead to decorticate posturing, not decerebrate.

questions.text: In the figure shown below, mechanism of action of valproate is best represented by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

The mechanism of action of valproate is best represented by A in the diagram, which shows inhibition of GABA transaminase and increased GABA synthesis, leading to increased CNS GABA levels.

 

Mechanism of Valproate

 

  • Valproate increases GABA in the brain by:
    • Inhibiting GABA transaminase (enzyme responsible for GABA degradation), thus reducing breakdown of GABA.
    • Stimulating glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD), enhancing GABA synthesis.
  • This is illustrated at the point labeled A in the diagram, where GABA degradation is inhibited and GABA synthesis is promoted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B: Facilitates GABA release (not the main action of valproate).

 

Option C. C: Inhibits GABA reuptake (not the primary valproate effect).

 

Option D. D: Barbiturates and benzodiazepines modulate the GABA-A receptor

questions.text: A 5 year old patient presents to the OPD with dysphagia, dysarthria, and dysphonia. On examination, brisk jaw jerk is seen. What is the possible localisation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticobulbar tracts 

 

The clinical features—dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and a brisk jaw jerk—localize the lesion to the corticobulbar tracts.

 

Controls muscles innervated by cranial nerves; UMN lesion leads to pseudobulbar symptoms and brisk jaw jerk.

 

Case Analysis

 

  • Dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia: Indicate dysfunction of cranial nerves supplied by the bulbar region (IX, X, XII) and are signs of pseudobulbar palsy.
  • Brisk jaw jerk: This is an exaggerated deep tendon reflex, suggesting involvement of upper motor neurons innervating the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), typically via the corticobulbar tract.
  • Corticobulbar tract lesions commonly produce pseudobulbar symptoms and hyperactive jaw jerk.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Corticospinal tracts: Involved in limb motor control; would result in spasticity and brisk limb reflexes, not bulbar symptoms.

 

Option C. Mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus: Associated with jaw position/proprioception, not jaw jerk and bulbar palsy.

 

Option D. V3 nerve: Lesion would cause LMN signs like jaw deviation, not brisk jaw jerk or bulbar signs.

questions.text: 65-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation comes to the office due to numbness of his left hand for the past 3 weeks. When the eyes are closed, he is unable to recognize the letters written on his left hand with a stylus. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+. Gait is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following locations of the brain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

The finding of astereognosis (inability to recognize objects or letters by touch, despite normal strength and sensation otherwise) with a history of atrial fibrillation suggests a stroke affecting the contralateral primary somatosensory cortex in the parietal lobe.

 

Case Analysis

 

  • Astereognosis: Characteristic of lesions involving the primary somatosensory cortex, specifically the postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe.
  • Normal motor function, reflexes, gait: Rules out motor cortex, cerebellum, or brainstem involvement.
  • Atrial fibrillation: Risk factor for embolic stroke.
  • Left hand involvement points to right hemisphere lesion (by brain symmetry; image is a left lateral brain, but answer is based on the cortex’s role)

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady who is 2 weeks postpartum presents with headache, and acute episode of generalized seizures. The contrast-enhanced CT of the head is shown below. What is the drug of choice for the acute management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMWH 

 

The drug of choice for acute management of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) is low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Standard of care for CVST acute management.

 

Case Analysis

 

  • History: Postpartum, headache, seizures—classic risk factors and presentation for CVST.
  • Image: Contrast-enhanced CT shows a filling defect. 
  • Treatment: Acute management requires anticoagulation, with LMWH as the preferred agent to prevent clot propagation and facilitate recanalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Labetalol: Used in acute hypertension, not CVST.

 

Option B. IV MgSO4: First-line for eclampsia, not indicated here.

 

Option D. Aspirin: Not indicated for acute CVST; anticoagulation is preferred

questions.text: An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fiber is given. What is the most commonly affected area in Guillain-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1  

 

The most commonly affected area in Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) is the myelin sheath, which is labeled as 1 in the electron microscopic image.

 

Identification of Structures

 

  • 1: Myelin sheath—dark, multilayered structure surrounding the axon.
  • 2: Axon—the central core inside the sheath.
  • 3: Schwann cell nucleus—located adjacent to the nerve fiber, involved in myelination.
  • 4: Schwann cell cytoplasm—surrounding the myelinated axon.

 

Pathophysiological Basis

 

  • Guillain-Barre syndrome is an acute demyelinating polyneuropathy in which the immune system attacks the myelin sheath of peripheral nerves, leading to motor weakness and sometimes sensory changes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has developed persistent food-seeking behavior over the past few months. His mother initially thought that the boy was undergoing a growth spurt, but despite how much she fed him he never seemed satisfied. The patient has also started complaining of a headache and nausea in the morning. His physical examination is significant for BMI of 32 kg/m2. This patient's food-seeking behavior could be explained by a lesion causing hyperactivity of which hypothalamic nucleus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral

 

The patient's persistent food-seeking behavior and obesity indicate hyperactivity or loss of inhibition of the lateral hypothalamic nucleus, which is known as the "feeding center".

 

  • The lateral hypothalamic nucleus (LHN) stimulates hunger and feeding behavior.
  • Lesions in this area cause loss of hunger (aphagia), while hyperactivity or stimulation leads to increased feeding and obesity.
  • The patient's symptoms of persistent hunger despite eating and increased BMI are consistent with lateral hypothalamic nucleus hyperactivity or an abnormal lesion causing its stimulation.
  • Associated signs of increased intracranial pressure (morning headache, nausea) suggest a possible hypothalamic tumor or mass effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior nucleus: Mainly involved in heat loss and parasympathetic (cooling) activities.

 

Option C. Supraoptic nucleus: Produces ADH and oxytocin, involved in water balance, not feeding

 

Option D. Ventromedial nucleus: The "satiety center"; lesions here cause hyperphagia and obesity, but hyperactivity results in anorexia.

questions.text: If you see the word "yellow," you'll likely recognize "banana" faster than "television" because yellow and banana are more closely linked in memory.  Which of the following structures is this concept dependent on?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neocortex 

 

  • The neocortex integrates and stores semantic associations, such as linking the color "yellow" with the object "banana."
  • The hippocampus is key for forming new episodic memories but is less involved in well-established semantic links.
  • The amygdala is primarily involved with emotional memory and fear responses.
  • The striatum relates to procedural memory and habit learning.

choices.text: Romberg sign with loss of DTR

questions.text: What would be the likely “classical” presentation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cape like distribution

 

The classical presentation for the MRI shown—which depicts a central cord lesion in the cervical spine—is a cape-like distribution of sensory loss.

 

  • The MRI image demonstrates a syrinx or central cord expansion within the cervical spinal cord, typical of syringomyelia.
  • Syringomyelia leads to bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in a "cape-like" distribution over the shoulders, arms, and upper back, due to disruption of the crossing fibers of the spinothalamic tract in the anterior white commissure.
  • Other features (loss of DTR, UMN+LMN signs, preserved dorsal column function) are less specific or do not fully explain the described imaging and symptomatology.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are typically associated with delirium?


1. Impaired consciousness
2. Altered sleep-wake cycle 
3. Normal EEG
4. Carphologia 
5. Autonomic Dysfunction
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 5 

 

The features typically associated with delirium include:

 

  1. Impaired consciousness (reduced awareness and attention)
  2. Altered sleep-wake cycle (disturbances in normal circadian rhythm)
  3. Carphologia (picking at imaginary objects or clothing)
  4. Autonomic dysfunction (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension, sweating)

 

The EEG in delirium is usually abnormal, showing generalized slowing, so normal EEG (3) is not typical.

 

  • 1, 2, 4, 5 are characteristic features of delirium.
  • 3 (Normal EEG) is not typical; EEG is usually abnormal in delirium

questions.text: A motorcyclist suffered a head injury 6 months back and presents with persistent memory deficits following injury. Choose the most appropriately matched option related to memory?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial Temporal lobe - Declarative memory

 

  • The medial temporal lobe, including the hippocampus, is critical for the formation and consolidation of declarative memory (facts and events).
  • Hippocampus specifically supports declarative, not implicit memory (which is procedural and involves other brain regions like the striatum).
  • Neocortex is involved in higher-order processing and storage of semantic memory but not specifically associative learning per se.
  • Angular gyrus is involved in language and number processing but not procedural memory,

questions.text: A 65 year old patient has normal fluency and repetition of speech but impaired naming and comprehension. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transcortical sensory aphasia

 

The clinical presentation—normal fluency and repetition but impaired naming and comprehension—is characteristic of transcortical sensory aphasia.

 

  • Transcortical sensory aphasia:
    • Fluent speech
    • Good repetition
    • Poor comprehension and naming

choices.text: It is a Chloride channel opener.
It also has anti-epileptic activity against focal seizures
It can lead to hyponatremia in the elderly

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman came to the hospital with complaints of excruciating paroxysmal pain on the right side of her lips, gums, and cheek. The episodes last for 2-3 min. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the primary drug used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a Chloride channel opener. 

 

The clinical presentation of excruciating, paroxysmal facial pain lasting 2-3 minutes suggests trigeminal neuralgia, and the first-line primary drug used for this condition is carbamazepine.

 

Carbamazepine primarily works by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, stabilizing hyperexcited neural membranes; it is not a chloride channel opener (that mechanism is more typical of drugs like benzodiazepines or barbiturates).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can cause agranulocytosis: True. Carbamazepine can cause serious bone marrow suppression including agranulocytosis.

 

Option C. It also has anti-epileptic activity against focal seizures: True. Carbamazepine is widely used in focal epilepsy.

 

Option D. It can lead to hyponatremia in the elderly: True. Carbamazepine can cause SIADH resulting in hyponatremia

choices.text: Enhancing the effect of endogenous dopamine

questions.text: 72-year-old man with a history of Parkinson disease comes to the OPD for follow-up. The patient has been taking carbidopa-levodopa since being diagnosed 5 years ago and has required increasing doses to control his symptoms. He is now taking the maximum dose but  reports worsening stiffness and difficulty moving between his scheduled doses; these symptoms improve after he takes the medication. Entacapone is added to his treatment regimen. This drug is most likely to improve this patient's symptoms through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreasing peripheral levodopa degradation

 

The symptoms described represent “wearing-off” phenomena in Parkinson’s disease treated with carbidopa-levodopa. Adding entacapone improves symptoms by:

 

Decreasing peripheral levodopa degradation

 

  • Entacapone is a COMT (catechol-O-methyltransferase) inhibitor, which inhibits the peripheral breakdown of levodopa into inactive metabolites, thereby increasing its availability to the brain.
  • This leads to more stable and prolonged plasma levodopa levels, reducing motor fluctuations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Directly stimulating dopamine receptors: Direct dopamine receptor stimulation is the effect of dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole), not entacapone.

 

Option C. Enhancing the effect of endogenous dopamine: Enhancing endogenous dopamine action is indirect and vague; entacapone acts by inhibiting levodopa degradation.

 

Option D. Inhibiting central muscarinic receptors: Central muscarinic receptor inhibition is the mechanism of anticholinergics, unrelated to entacapone.

questions.text: Thalidomide should not be used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HIV-assosiated peripheral neuropathy 

 

  •  Thalidomide is contraindicated in peripheral neuropathy because it can worsen or precipitate neuropathic damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV-associated aphthous ulcers: Thalidomide has been used for treatment of severe, refractory aphthous ulcers in HIV patients.


Option C. Behçet syndrome: Effective in treating severe mucocutaneous manifestations and oral/genital ulcers.


Option D. Erythema nodosum leprosum: One of the main indications for thalidomide, where it provides dramatic improvement.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had similar episodes in the past where the headache usually lasts for 1-2 days. Bright light increases her discomfort and she prefers sitting in a dark room. Which of the following are used to prevent further episodes of this condition?

 

1. Sumatriptan

2. Propranolol

3. Naproxen

4. Topiramate
questions.solution: Ans. A) 2 and 4

choices.text: It results in focal seizures with dyscognitive features
The person experiences an aura before the seizure
It is associated with a family history of epilepsy
Seizures can be controlled with anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the following pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seizures can be controlled with anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine

 

  •  The question likely refers to mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (eg. hippocampal sclerosis) — these cause focal dyscognitive seizures with auras and often have familial tendencies, but they are frequently drug-resistant, so stating they can be reliably controlled with medications like carbamazepine is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal seizures with dyscognitive features: True; temporal lobe epilepsy typically produces complex (dyscognitive) focal seizures.


Option B. Aura before the seizure: True; an aura is a common initial symptom reflecting focal onset.


Option C. Associated with a family history of epilepsy: True; some focal epilepsies, including temporal lobe epilepsy, show familial clustering.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with progressive atrophy and weakness in her hands and forearms. On examination, she is found to have spasticity of the legs. Which of the following is the least likely feature to suggest ALS?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Impaired bowel and bladder function 

 

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disorder involving both:

 

  • Upper motor neurons (UMN): Spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign
  • Lower motor neurons (LMN): Fasciculations, muscle atrophy, weakness

 

Impaired bowel and bladder function is NOT a typical feature; autonomic and sphincter functions are usually preserved in ALS, so their involvement points against the diagnosis.

 

Hence, impaired bowel and bladder function is least likely in ALS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Babinski positive: Expected — due to UMN involvement.

 

Option B. Spontaneous fasciculations: Common LMN sign.

 

Option D. Preserved ocular mobility: ALS usually spares ocular muscles until very late in disease.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

 

  • Flocculonodular lobe = vestibulocerebellum → Balance + Eye movements → Lesion → Staggering gait + Nystagmus + Romberg + postural instability.
  • This fits the clinical vignette → hence option A.

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings located deep within the skin and other tissues. They are highly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them particularly adept at detecting fast vibrations. These receptors are crucial for perceiving textures and fine details through vibration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ruffini - Fine touch: This is incorrect because Ruffini endings are mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch, not fine touch. They are deeper in the skin and contribute to the sensation of skin deformation, which is associated with stretch rather than fine touch.

 

Option C. Meissner - Stretch: This is incorrect because Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch, not stretch. They are located near the surface of the skin and are sensitive to changes in texture and slow vibrations.

 

Option D. Merkel - Slow vibration: This is incorrect because Merkel cells are associated with fine touch and two-point discrimination, not slow vibrations. They are particularly sensitive to edges, points, and textures, which aids in tasks like reading Braille.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: A 70-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department due to sudden onset of right-sided weakness and urinary incontinence that began about 10 hours ago. On examination, there is 4/5 strength in the right upper extremity, 1/5 strength in the right lower extremity, and a Babinski sign on the right side. Sensation is decreased throughout the right foot and leg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left Anterior cerebral artery stroke 

 

  • ACA supplies medial frontal & parietal lobes → motor & sensory for contralateral lower limb.
  • Features here: severe right leg weakness, sensory loss in leg, Babinski sign, and urinary incontinence → classical for left ACA infarct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lacunar stroke:

 

  • Produces pure motor or pure sensory strokes without cortical signs.
  • This patient has urinary incontinence & cortical involvement → not lacunar.

 

Option C. Left middle cerebral artery stroke:

 

  • MCA infarct → contralateral face/arm > leg weakness + aphasia/neglect.
  • Here leg is more involved than arm, so MCA ruled out.

 

Option D. Right ACA stroke:

 

  • Would cause left-sided weakness & sensory loss (contralateral to lesion).
  • Patient has right-sided deficits, so not right ACA.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of lower leg weakness, swallowing difficulty, and drooling of saliva. He has not yet received any childhood vaccinations. Two days after admission, the patient develops shortness of breath. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 64%. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient dies of respiratory failure. At autopsy, examination of the spinal cord shows destruction of the anterior horn cells. Neurological examination of this patient would have most likely shown which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyporeflexia

 

  • Anterior horn cells = lower motor neurons (LMN).
  • Damage leads to LMN signs: muscle weakness, hypotonia, fasciculations, hyporeflexia/areflexia.
  • Classical for poliomyelitis (unvaccinated child, anterior horn cell destruction).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive Babinski sign: Indicates UMN lesion (corticospinal tract damage), not LMN.

 

Option B. Clasp knife spasticity: Also a feature of UMN lesions due to loss of inhibitory control.

 

Option D. Sensory loss: Sensory pathways remain intact in polio → no sensory deficit.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy presents with fever, headache, irritability, nuchal rigidity, and photophobia. CSF analysis shows:

Glucose: 60 mg/dL

Protein: 80 mg/dL

RBCs: 2/mm³

WBCs: 85/mm³ (10% neutrophils, 70% lymphocytes, 20% monocytes)

Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Group B coxsackievirus

 

  • Viral meningitis (aseptic meningitis):
    • Glucose → normal
    • Protein → mildly elevated
    • WBCs → lymphocytic predominance
  • Coxsackievirus (Enterovirus, esp. Group B) is the most common cause of viral meningitis in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans:

 

  • Usually in immunocompromised (HIV).
  • CSF shows very high opening pressure, low glucose, high protein, lymphocytes.
  • Not typical in an immunocompetent 4-year-old.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

 

  • TB meningitis → very low glucose, high protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis.
  • This case has normal glucose, so not TB.

 

Option D. Neisseria meningitidis:

 

  • Bacterial meningitis → low glucose, high protein, neutrophilic pleocytosis.
  • Here → glucose is normal + lymphocytes predominant → excludes bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: An investigator is studying cellular repair mechanisms in various tissues. One of the samples being reviewed is from the anterior horn of the spinal cord of a patient who was involved in a snowboard accident. Pathologic examination of the biopsy specimen shows dispersion of the Nissl bodies, swelling of the neuronal body, and a displacement of the nucleus to the periphery in numerous cells. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the observed findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Central chromatolysis

 

Central chromatolysis is the neuronal cell-body response to axonal injury — features include dispersion of Nissl substance, cellular swelling, and eccentric displacement of the nucleus as the neuron upregulates protein synthesis to support axonal regeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurodegenerative changes: Usually a chronic process with neuronal loss, Lewy bodies, neurofibrillary tangles, etc., not the acute Nissl dispersal and cell swelling seen here.


Option B. Wallerian degeneration: Refers to degeneration of the axon distal to the site of injury, not the characteristic soma changes (Nissl dispersion) described.


Option D. Reactive astrogliosis: Involves proliferation/hypertrophy of astrocytes (GFAP+) after CNS injury, not the neuronal Nissl and nuclear displacement findings.

questions.text: All of the following are tauopathies, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM behavioral disorder

 

Tauopathies are neurodegenerative diseases characterized by abnormal aggregation of hyperphosphorylated tau protein in neurons and glia. Examples include Pick’s disease, corticobasal degeneration, and progressive supranuclear palsy.


REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a parasomnia, not a tauopathy. It is most often associated with α-synucleinopathies (e.g., Parkinson’s disease, Lewy body dementia, multiple system atrophy).

 

Linked to α-synucleinopathies, not a tauopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pick’s disease: A frontotemporal lobar degeneration with Pick bodies (tau inclusions).


Option B. Corticobasal degeneration: A tauopathy with asymmetric cortical atrophy and basal ganglia involvement.


Option C. Progressive supranuclear palsy: A classic tauopathy with supranuclear gaze palsy and postural instability.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with steroids. MRI shows the following changes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuromyelitis optica

 

  • The patient has recurrent episodes of vision loss in both eyes, which improve with steroids.
  • MRI changes (classically long-segment involvement in the spinal cord here but can show optic nerve inflammation also) support demyelinating pathology.

  • Neuromyelitis optica (Devic’s disease) is characterized by:

    • Severe, recurrent optic neuritis → visual loss.
    • Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (spinal cord lesions extending ≥3 vertebral segments).
    • Strong association with anti-AQP4 (aquaporin-4) antibodies.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hereditary spastic quadriplegia: Genetic disorder presenting in childhood with progressive spasticity, not episodic visual loss.

 

Option B. Subacute combined degeneration: Seen in Vitamin B12 deficiency. Presents with posterior column (loss of vibration & proprioception) and corticospinal tract involvement, not optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: Also causes optic neuritis, but MS usually has short-segment spinal lesions on MRI, whereas NMO shows long-segment cord lesions with more severe optic nerve involvement.

questions.text: A previously healthy 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of confusion for 2 hours. His wife reports that he fell and hit his head while changing a ceiling light the previous evening. On arrival, he is unconscious. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8ºF), pulse is 54/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 198/106 mm Hg. The right pupil is dilated and fixed; the left pupil is round and reactive to light. There is extension of the extremities to painful stimuli. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A mannitol infusion is begun. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows herniation of the right medial temporal lobe. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right-sided hemiplegia

 

This patient has uncal (transtentorial) herniation due to head trauma → temporal lobe compresses against tentorium cerebelli.

 

Key features:

 

  • Dilated, fixed ipsilateral pupil → compression of ipsilateral CN III (oculomotor nerve).
  • Hemiplegia on the same side (ipsilateral hemiplegia) → due to compression of contralateral cerebral peduncle against tentorium (Kernohan’s notch phenomenon → “false localizing sign”).
  • Cushing’s triad seen here: hypertension + bradycardia + irregular breathing.
  • Decerebrate posturing (extension to pain) suggests midbrain/upper pons involvement.

 

Thus, the most likely finding is right-sided hemiplegia (same side as the dilated pupil).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bilateral spasticity: Suggests diffuse upper motor neuron lesions (eg, advanced ALS, spinal cord injury), not acute herniation.

 

Option C. Bilateral lower limb paralysis: More typical of anterior cerebral artery infarction, not uncal herniation.

 

Option D. Right eye esotropia and elevation: Seen in CN VI (abducens) palsy, but here the oculomotor nerve is affected → causing down & out eye with ptosis and mydriasis, not esotropia.

questions.text:
Disorders of autonomic function should be considered in patients with:

 

  1. Unexplained orthostatic hypotension
  2. Dysuria
  3. Hyperhidrosis
  4. Urinary incontinence
  5. Dementia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 4

 

Disorders of the autonomic nervous system (ANS) can manifest in multiple organ systems because the ANS regulates cardiovascular, urinary, gastrointestinal, and sweat gland function.

 

  • (1) Unexplained orthostatic hypotension → classic feature of autonomic failure due to impaired sympathetic vasoconstriction.
  • (3) Hyperhidrosis → abnormal sympathetic cholinergic activity.
  • (4) Urinary incontinence → impaired parasympathetic/sympathetic control of bladder.

 

These three features strongly suggest autonomic dysfunction.

 

2  (Dysuria) – Dysuria is usually due to infection/structural causes, not autonomic dysfunction 

 

5 (Dementia) – Dementia is cortical, not a primary autonomic disorder.

choices.text: GBS deteriorates >8 weeks after onset or relapses at least two times
GBS deteriorates >5 weeks after onset or relapses at least three times
GBS deteriorates >9 weeks after onset or relapses at least three times
GBS deteriorates >5 weeks after onset or relapses at least two times

questions.text: In a patient with Guillain-Barre syndrome, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy is suspected when_____.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) GBS deteriorates >9 weeks after onset or relapses at least three times

 

Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP). By definition, it is monophasic with progression up to 4 weeks, followed by plateau and recovery.

 

If the disease course extends longer or relapses occur, one should suspect chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP).

 

  • CIDP is suspected when:
    • Progression or relapse > 8–9 weeks after onset
    • OR ≥ 3 relapses

 

Thus, the cut-off >9 weeks or ≥3 relapses distinguishes CIDP from recurrent or relapsing GBS.

questions.text: In patients with multiple sclerosis, which of the following is used to determine neurological impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kurtzke expanded disability status scale

 

In Multiple Sclerosis (MS), neurological impairment and disability are quantified using the Kurtzke Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS).

 

  • It is a widely used functional scale ranging from 0 (normal neuro exam) to 10 (death due to MS).
  • It measures disability across multiple functional systems (FS): pyramidal, cerebellar, brainstem, sensory, bowel/bladder, visual, cerebral/mental.
  • Commonly used in clinical trials and follow-up of MS patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modified Well’s score: Used for assessing probability of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), not MS.

 

Option B. Hess and Hunt’s scale: Used for SAH

 

Option D. Revised McDonald criteria: Used for the diagnosis of MS, not disability quantification.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coronary artery disease.

 

  • Patients with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) have a 2–3× higher risk of cardiovascular disease compared to the general population.
  • Chronic systemic inflammation accelerates atherosclerosis, leading to premature coronary artery disease, which is the most common cause of death in RA patients.
  • Risk is further worsened by traditional factors (HTN, dyslipidemia, smoking) and RA-specific factors (disease activity, corticosteroid use).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atlantoaxial subluxation:

 

  • A serious neurological complication of long-standing RA.
  • Can cause spinal cord compression → sudden death (rare), but not the most common cause.

 

Option B. Interstitial lung disease (ILD):

 

  • RA can cause pulmonary fibrosis and ILD, which contribute to morbidity and mortality.
  • However, not the leading cause compared to CAD.

 

Option D. Gastrointestinal bleeding:

 

  • More related to NSAID/steroid therapy in RA patients.
  • Important but not the top cause of death.

questions.text: 42-year-old woman comes to the office due to worsening double vision and gait unsteadiness. She states she had cramping abdominal pain and diarrhoea 2 weeks ago after an outdoor picnic which spontaneously resolved after 3 days. The double vision began 4 days ago and is persistent and progressive. She has had no fever, headache, neck pain, photophobia, or bowel or bladder dysfunction.  On physical examination, she is fully alert and oriented with normal memory, speech, and language comprehension. There is mild ptosis of the right eye with weakness of the medial and upward gaze. Left eye movements are normal. Bilateral lower-extremity weakness with loss of deep tendon reflexes is present. Bilateral upper-extremity muscle strength, reflexes, and coordination are normal. Sensation to touch and pinprick is normal throughout.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immune-mediated nerve injury

 

This patient most likely has Miller-Fisher syndrome (MFS), a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).

 

Key features:

 

  • History of diarrheal illness 2 weeks ago → most often Campylobacter jejuni infection.
  • Ophthalmoplegia → weakness of extraocular muscles (ptosis, impaired medial/upward gaze).
  • Ataxia & gait unsteadiness.
  • Areflexia (loss of reflexes) in the legs.
  • Preserved sensation.

 

Pathogenesis: Immune-mediated demyelination of peripheral nerves due to molecular mimicry (antibodies against gangliosides, eg. GQ1b).

questions.text: An elderly man presents with clinical findings are shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriatic arthritis

 

The most likely diagnosis for the clinical findings shown in the image is psoriatic arthritis.

 

Key Features in the Image

 

  • Swollen, deformed toes ("sausage digits" or dactylitis)
  • Skin changes: erythema, scaling, nail changes (onycholysis, pitting), ulcerations
  • Asymmetrical distribution
  • Psoriatic arthritis is often associated with psoriasis, presenting as dactylitis, nail changes, and asymmetric joint involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septic arthritis: Septic arthritis usually affects a single joint and is associated with systemic illness.

 

Option B. Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis typically causes bony enlargement and Heberden/Bouchard nodes, not sausage digits or nail changes.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is more symmetric and often involves MCP/PIP joints, with less pronounced nail and skin changes.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions predominantly involve the upper lobe of the lung?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis


The condition among the options that predominantly involves the upper lobes of the lung is Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) with its associated lung fibrosis.

 

Scleroderma involves predominantly the lower lobes of the lung with interstitial fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis may cause upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis and apical fibrobullous disease as a late complication.

 

Option C. Asbestosis typically affects the lower lobes with pleural plaques.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis also favors lower lobe interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: 61-year-old male patient comes to the office complaining of involuntary shaking of his hands. It started on the right side but now his left handshakes as well. The shaking disappears with purposeful activity and worsens with emotional stress. He does not have a family history of tremors. Physical examination reveals a resting hand tremor with a frequency of 4-5 cycles/sec. There is some muscle rigidity of both arms. His gait and posture are normal. His mini mental status exam yields a score of 30/30. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trihexyphenidyl 

 

This patient presents with Parkinson’s disease features:

 

  • Resting tremor (classic "pill-rolling" tremor, 4–5 Hz).
  • Rigidity (cogwheel/stiffness).
  • Tremor disappears with voluntary movement and worsens with stress.
  • No cognitive impairment (MMSE 30/30).

 

In relatively young patients with Parkinson’s disease where tremor is the predominant symptom, anticholinergic drugs (e.g., Trihexyphenidyl, Benztropine) are preferred.
They help most with tremor and rigidity, but not bradykinesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clozapine: An atypical antipsychotic, sometimes used for drug-induced psychosis in Parkinson’s (because it has minimal extrapyramidal side effects).

 

Option B. Lorazepam: Benzodiazepine, used for essential tremor worsened by anxiety or alcohol withdrawal tremor.

 

Option C. Propranolol:

 

  • First-line for essential tremor (action/postural tremor).
  • Ineffective for resting tremor of Parkinson’s.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Essential tremor → action/postural, better with alcohol → Propranolol / Primidone.
  • Parkinson’s tremor → resting, 4–6 Hz, improves with movement → Trihexyphenidyl (young) or Levodopa (elderly/severe disability).
  • Drug-induced parkinsonism (e.g., from antipsychotics) → Trihexyphenidyl or Benztropine.

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

 

  1. Preferred site for DBS for tremor reduction
  2. Hemiballismus results from a lesion at this site
  3. Chorea results from a lesion at this site
  4. Athetosis is a result of a lesion at this site
  5. Parkinsonism occurs due to defect here
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-E, 2-E, 3-A, 4-C, 5-D

 

 And Structure Identification

 

  • A: Caudate nucleus
  • B: Putamen
  • C: Globus pallidus
  • D: Substantia nigra
  • E: Subthalamic nucleus

 

Key Points

 

  • Subthalamic nucleus is the target for DBS and is involved in hemiballismus.
  • Caudate nucleus lesions result in chorea as seen in Huntington’s disease.
  • Globus pallidus lesions result in athetosis.
  • Parkinson’s disease is due to degeneration of the substantia nigra.

questions.text: 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after he develops dificulty speaking. When asked about the onset of his symptoms, the patient slowly responds with "weak... morning..." and becomes very frustrated. On examination, he is able to state his first name but with difficulty, and correctly points to different body parts on command. This patient's speech difficulties are most likely caused by a lesion affecting which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

  • Broca’s aphasia is classically caused by infarction of the territory supplied by the left MCA, [LEFT is the dominant hemisphere ]particularly its superior division.
  • The examination findings (non-fluent speech, good comprehension, frustration) confirm Broca’s (expressive) aphasia, which is supplied by D in this image.

 

  • A and B: These arrows point to the Anterior Cerebral Arteries (ACA), specifically showing the A1 segments before they merge to form the anterior communicating artery.
  • C: This arrow indicates the Right Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA), a major artery supplying blood to large parts of the brain.
  • D: This arrow points to a left Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) on the opposite side.
  • E: This arrow indicates the Basilar Artery, formed by the union of the two vertebral arteries, and located at the base of the brain

questions.text: Ischemia occurs in the brain when the cerebral blood flow falls below _____.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20 mL/100 g/min

 

Ischemia in the brain occurs when the cerebral blood flow (CBF) falls below 20 mL/100 g/min.

 

  • Normal CBF is approximately 50-60 mL/100 g/min.
  • When CBF declines below 20 mL/100 g/min, brain tissue becomes ischemic and unable to maintain normal function, leading to cellular injury.
  • Below this threshold, ATP production is impaired, impairing ion pumps and causing cell damage.

questions.text: A 90-year-old female suffers an ischemic stroke in the context of diffuse atherosclerotic disease and dies four days later despite appropriate treatment. The predominant cell type seen on postmortem brain biopsy functions most similarly to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Monocyte

 

The predominant cell type seen in the brain after an ischemic stroke, especially a few days later, is the monocyte-derived macrophage (microglia activated and recruited monocytes).

 

  • After ischemic stroke, inflammatory response involves infiltration of blood-derived monocytes, which differentiate into macrophages and clear necrotic tissue.
  • These monocyte-derived macrophages function similarly to peripheral monocytes, participating in phagocytosis and immune regulation.
  • Neutrophils are early responders but decrease after the first 24-48 hours.
  • Eosinophils, T-lymphocytes, and B-lymphocytes are less prominent in acute ischemic infarcts.

choices.text: Positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites on urinalysis
Elevated IgG and myelin basic protein on CSF analysis
Elevated post-void residual volume on bladder ultrasound

questions.text: A 50-year-old gravida 2, para 2 female presents with urinary incontinence. She reports daily episodes of a sudden need to void and has started to wear adult diapers. She also has intermittent motor and sensory loss, decreased visual acuity with painful eye movements, and worsening symptoms in summer. Further workup is most likely to reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated IgG and myelin basic protein on CSF analysis

 

  • MS is a demyelinating disease causing neurological deficits including optic neuritis, motor/sensory symptoms, and neurogenic bladder leading to urgency and incontinence.
  • Symptom worsening in summer (Uhthoff phenomenon) is classic for MS.
  • CSF analysis in MS typically shows elevated IgG and myelin basic protein, reflecting demyelination and immune activation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents with visual changes, diplopia, and weakness worsening throughout the day. Ice pack test improves eyelid drooping. Chest X-ray shows an anterior mediastinal mass. Which of the following shares an embryonic origin with the cells of this mass?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parathyroid glands

 

Parathyroid glands (inferior parathyroids from the third pharyngeal pouch):

 

The patient’s presentation—ptosis improving with ice pack test, fluctuating weakness worsening through the day, and an anterior mediastinal mass on chest X-ray—is diagnostic of myasthenia gravis with a thymoma.

 

  • Inferior parathyroids derive from the third pharyngeal pouch (shared embryonic origin with thymus).
  • Superior parathyroids derive from the fourth pouch.

 

Embryonic Origin of Thymoma

 

  • The thymus (source of thymoma) originates from the third pharyngeal pouch during embryonic development.
  • Structures derived from the third pharyngeal pouch include:
  • Thymus
  • Inferior parathyroid glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian tube: Derived from the first pharyngeal pouch.

 

Option C. Greater horn of hyoid: Derived from the third pharyngeal arch (mesoderm), not the pouch.

 

Option D. Thyroid gland: Derived from the floor of the primitive pharynx (endoderm), not a pharyngeal pouch.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

 

  • Methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine are considered first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) for rheumatoid arthritis management.
  • Azathioprine is generally considered a second-line or alternative immunosuppressant due to its side effect profile and is not routinely used as a first-line agent for RA

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to a 3-month history of painful, swollen wrists and knees. She also has joint stiffness, which is worse upon wakening and limits her daily activities. The patient's only other medical condition is hypothyroidism for which she takes levothyroxine. Plain radiographs of the joints show joint space narrowing and marginal erosions. Which of the following cytokines are primarily involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's joint destruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IL-1 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha

 

The patient’s presentation of painful, swollen joints with morning stiffness, joint space narrowing, and marginal erosions on X-ray is characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

 

Cytokines involved in RA pathogenesis

 

  • IL-1 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) are key pro-inflammatory cytokines driving synovial inflammation and joint destruction in RA.
  • IL-1 stimulates cartilage degradation and bone resorption.
  • TNF-α promotes inflammation, pannus formation, and joint damage.
  • Other cytokines listed (IL-2, IFN-γ, IL-4, IL-5, IL-10, TGF-β) have different immunoregulatory roles but are less central to the destructive process of RA.

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to worsening abdominal pain and vomiting. Urgent laparotomy reveals bilateral renal infarcts and multiple segments of necrosis and perforation in the small bowel. Microscopic examination of the vessel walls shows diffuse inflammation of the adventitia and marked thickening of the inner layers due to proliferation of loose connective tissue; the arterial lumen is significantly narrowed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyarteritis nodosa 

 

The clinical presentation of abdominal pain, vomiting, bilateral renal infarcts, small bowel necrosis and perforation, along with histopathology showing diffuse inflammation of the adventitia, thickening of the inner arterial layers and luminal narrowing, is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).

 

  • PAN is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis affecting medium-sized muscular arteries, causing ischemic infarction of affected organs like kidneys and intestines.
  • Histology shows transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis, adventitial inflammation, and intimal thickening leading to vessel narrowing and ischemia.
  • Unlike microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis, PAN does not involve small vessels or cause granulomas and typically spares the lungs(option B and D)
  • Bacterial endocarditis causes septic emboli but does not produce this typical vasculitis histology(option A)

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician due to painful urination. Physical examination shows a watery penile discharge. Urethral swabs obtained from the patient are negative for gonococcal infection. He is treated appropriately and his symptoms resolve. Two weeks later, he develops acute conjunctivitis, right knee pain, and vesicular rash on his palms and soles. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sacroilitis

 

The patient's presentation of urethritis with watery discharge, negative gonococcal test, followed by conjunctivitis, arthritis (right knee pain), and vesicular rash on palms and soles is characteristic of reactive arthritis (Reiter syndrome).

 

  • Reactive arthritis typically occurs after a urethritis or gastrointestinal infection, often caused by Chlamydia trachomatis in non-gonococcal urethritis.
  • The classic triad includes urethritis, conjunctivitis, and arthritis.
  • Sacroilitis is a common feature of reactive arthritis and is part of the seronegative spondyloarthropathies group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal dysmotility: Esophageal dysmotility is seen in scleroderma.

 

Option B. Polymyositis: Polymyositis causes proximal muscle weakness without urethritis or conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Tabes dorsalis: Tabes dorsalis is a late neurosyphilis manifestation with sensory ataxia.

choices.text: Autoantibodies to host cell basement membranes
Immune complex deposition in glomerular mesangium

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for arthralgias. Physical examination is shown. The knees are tender but do not appear warm or swollen. Urinalysis results are as follows:

Protein: 2+

Blood: moderate 

Leukocyte esterase: trace

White blood cells: 1-2/hpf

Red blood cells (RBCs): many/hpf

Casts: RBC casts

Which of the following mechanisms is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's renal findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immune complex deposition in glomerular mesangium

 

The most likely mechanism underlying this patient's renal findings is immune complex deposition in the glomerular mesangium.

 

Case Analysis

 

  • Clinical Findings: Young boy with palpable purpura on lower extremities (image), arthralgias, and urine findings of proteinuria, hematuria, RBC casts.
  • Diagnosis: This is classic for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), now called IgA vasculitis, which is a small-vessel vasculitis characterized by the tetrad of palpable purpura, arthralgias, abdominal pain, and renal involvement.
