  • Renal Pathology: Glomerular involvement in HSP is due to IgA immune complex deposition in the mesangium of glomeruli, leading to hematuria and proteinuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoantibodies against podocyte antigens: Seen in minimal change disease and membranous nephropathy, not HSP.

 

Option B. Autoantibodies to host cell basement membranes: Seen in Goodpasture’s syndrome (anti-GBM disease), not HSP.

 

Option D. Thrombosis of glomerular capillaries: Would cause acute renal injury but not explain the clinical scenario.

questions.text: A woman, 35 years old, arrives with symptoms of skin thickening, weakened muscles, and paleness in the extremities when exposed to cold temperatures. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase are observed, and a muscle biopsy reveals perifascicular infiltration. Which antibody is linked to these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody 

 

The clinical presentation suggests mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) or an overlap syndrome involving features of scleroderma (skin thickening, Raynaud's phenomenon) and myositis (muscle weakness, elevated creatine kinase, perifascicular muscle biopsy infiltration).

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with an overlap syndrome of polymyositis and scleroderma (systemic sclerosis), characterized by skin thickening, muscle inflammation, and Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Anti-U3 RNP is linked to systemic sclerosis with prominent pulmonary hypertension.

 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Anti-centromere antibody is associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome).

 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Anti-Jo-1 antibody is a marker for antisynthetase syndrome/myositis with interstitial lung disease, but not typically with scleroderma skin changes.

questions.text: All of the following can be given to a pregnant woman with SLE except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mycophenolate mofetil

 

The drug mycophenolate mofetil is contraindicated in pregnancy and should not be given to a pregnant woman with SLE due to its teratogenicity.

 

  • Hydroxychloroquine, azathioprine, and sulfasalazine are considered relatively safe and can be used during pregnancy in patients with SLE.
  • Mycophenolate mofetil is associated with a high risk of congenital malformations and pregnancy loss and must be avoided during pregnancy.,[teratogenic effects shown in the image below]

 

 

Other Teratogenic Effects seen are: large cleft lip and palate, micrognathia, ocular hypertelorism, microtia, external auditory duct atresia, left pelvic ectopic kidney, and complete agenesis of the corpus callosum.

questions.text: Which of the following anti rheumatoid drug increases extracellular adenosine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate

 

Methotrexate works primarily by inhibiting AICAR transformylase and thymidylate synthetase.

 

AICAR accumulates intracellularly and competes with AMP deaminase, resulting in AMP accumulation. AMP is released and converted extracellularly to adenosine, which is acts as the powerful anti-inflammatory agent. As a result, neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, and lymphocytes' inflammatory functions are suppressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leflunomide: Leflunomide inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, which is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidines, thereby suppressing the proliferation of activated lymphocytes. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option C. Sulphasalazine: Sulphasalazine is a prodrug that is metabolized into sulfapyridine and 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA). Its anti-inflammatory effects are primarily due to the action of 5-ASA. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: Hydroxychloroquine is thought to exert its anti-inflammatory effects by interfering with lysosomal activity and autophagy in immune cells, and by modulating the activity of toll-like receptors (TLRs). It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate increases extracellular adenosine by inhibiting AICAR transformylase, leading to the accumulation of AICAR, which competes with AMP deaminase and causes AMP to accumulate and be converted to adenosine outside the cell, thus exerting anti-inflammatory effects.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of sudden-onset fever, malaise, pain and swelling of his wrists and ankles that began a week ago. One month ago, he was started on hydralazine for adjunctive treatment of hypertension. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Examination shows swelling, tenderness, warmth, and erythema of both wrists and ankles; range of motion is limited. Further evaluation is most likely to show an increased level of which of the following autoantibodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-histone

 

  • The patient presents with fever, malaise, and symmetric arthritis shortly after starting hydralazine.
  • These are classic features of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE).
  • Anti-histone antibodies are highly sensitive and specific for DILE.
  • Hydralazine is one of the common drugs causing DILE (others: procainamide, isoniazid, TNF-α inhibitors).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-dsDNA: 

 

  • Highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Rarely positive in drug-induced lupus.

 

Option B. Anti-Smith:

 

  • Specific for SLE, rarely seen in DILE.

 

Option C. Anti-β2-glycoprotein:

 

  • Seen in antiphospholipid syndrome; not related to DILE.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a history of cold-induced color changes in her fingers, tight and shiny skin on her face and fingers, and small dilated blood vessels visible on her face. She also mentions difficulty in making certain facial expressions due to skin tightness. ANA staining pattern of the patient is shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Centromeric

 

The ANA staining pattern shown in the image is centromeric, which is most commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome).

 

Key Features from Image and Case

 

  • Image: The pattern shows discrete, dot-like staining within the nucleus—classic for centromere antibodies.
  • Clinical findings: Cold-induced color changes (Raynaud’s), tight, shiny skin, facial telangiectasias—all suggest CREST syndrome/limited systemic sclerosis.
  • Anti-centromere antibodies are highly specific for this form of scleroderma.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis and hemoptysis. HRCT is shown below. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C-ANCA

 

The most appropriate next investigation for an elderly patient presenting with cutaneous vasculitis and hemoptysis, with HRCT showing multiple large cavitating lung lesions, is C-ANCA (cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody).

 

  • C-ANCA (anti-PR3 antibody) is highly specific for Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis), which typically presents with:
    • Upper/lower respiratory tract involvement
    • Cutaneous vasculitis
    • Renal involvement
    • Cavitary lung lesions on HRCT, as seen in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-GBM: Is specific for Goodpasture's syndrome, which presents with hematuria and pulmonary hemorrhage, but not large cavitating lesions.

 

Option C. HbsAg: Screens for hepatitis B, unrelated to the described clinical picture.

 

Option D. P-ANCA: (MPO antibody) is more common in microscopic polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of severe pain in her left knee. To lose weight, she recently started jogging for 30 minutes a few times per week. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with metformin and chlorothiazide. On examination, her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 138/87 mm Hg. The left knee is swollen and tender to palpation with a significantly impaired range of motion. A 1.5 cm. painless ulcer is seen on the plantar surface of the left foot. Which of the following is most likely to help establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perform arthrocentesis

 

The clinical presentation of acute severe knee pain with swelling, fever, impaired range of motion, and a painless foot ulcer in a diabetic patient suggests possible septic arthritis or gouty arthritis, among other differential diagnoses.

 

  • Arthrocentesis (joint aspiration) is the most important diagnostic step to differentiate between septic arthritis, crystal-induced arthritis (gout or pseudogout), or inflammatory arthritis by analyzing synovial fluid for:
    • White blood cell count
    • Gram stain and culture (to identify infection)
    • Crystal analysis (urate or calcium pyrophosphate crystals).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Measuring HLA-B27: Is useful in diagnosing seronegative spondyloarthropathies, which is less likely here.

 

Option C. Measure rheumatoid factor: Rheumatoid factor is used in rheumatoid arthritis diagnosis but is less useful acutely.

 

Option D. Perform serum uric acid: Serum uric acid can be elevated in gout but is not diagnostic during an acute attack and cannot rule out infection

questions.text: A 30-year-old multiparous woman presents with chronic lower back pain. The pain is non-radiating, worse with activity, and improves with rest. There are no neurological deficits. X-ray pelvis shows bilateral symmetric sclerosis of the iliac side of the sacroiliac joints, with joint spaces preserved. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteitis condensans ilii

 

The most likely diagnosis for a multiparous woman with chronic non-radiating lower back pain, preserved sacroiliac joint spaces, and bilateral symmetric iliac-side sclerosis on pelvic X-ray is osteitis condensans ilii.

 

  • Osteitis condensans ilii presents with characteristic bilateral, symmetric triangular sclerosis of the iliac side of the sacroiliac joints, seen 
  • especially in multiparous women.

 

The joint spaces remain preserved and there are no associated neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and C. Ankylosing spondylitis and sacroiliitis: typically show erosions, joint space narrowing, or eventually ankylosis.

 

Option D. Metastatic bone disease: Metastatic bone disease would present with lytic or blastic lesions, not symmetric sclerosis limited to the iliac side of SI joints.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes for evaluation of persistent morning stiffness. She was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 4 months ago and was prescribed methotrexate. The patient currently takes the maximum tolerated dose, along with folic acid and as-needed naproxen. On examination, swelling, tenderness, and pain on range of motion are found at the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints and wrists bilaterally. Treatment with etanercept is considered. Which of the following tests should be performed before beginning treatment with this agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interferon gamma release assay

 

  • Etanercept is a TNF-α inhibitor, used in moderate-to-severe rheumatoid arthritis not responding to methotrexate.
  • TNF-α inhibitors increase the risk of reactivating latent tuberculosis (TB).
  • Screening for latent TB is mandatory before initiating therapy.
    • Options include: Tuberculin skin test (TST) or Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HRCT chest: Not required routinely before starting TNF-α inhibitors unless there is history of lung disease.

 

Option B. Echocardiogram: Only indicated if heart failure or prior cardiac history exists.

 

Option C. Fecal occult blood test: Used for colon cancer screening, not relevant for TNF-α inhibitor initiation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the OPD due to joint pain and stiffness in both hands for the past 6 months. He sometimes awakens with hand pain at night. Hand radiographs reveal bilateral erosions and joint deformities involving the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hereditary hemochromatosis

 

The diagnosis for the patient with bilateral erosions and joint deformities involving the second and third metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints is hereditary hemochromatosis, especially given the radiographic findings characteristic of this disease.

 

  • Hereditary hemochromatosis arthropathy classically involves the 2nd and 3rd MCP joints, with pain, stiffness, and radiographic changes including:
    • Symmetric joint space narrowing
    • Erosions
    • "Hook-like" or beak-like osteophytes on the radial aspect of metacarpal heads
    • Chondrocalcinosis (calcium pyrophosphate deposition) may also be present.
    • This arthropathy resembles rheumatoid arthritis clinically but is degenerative rather than inflammatory.
    • It typically presents in middle-aged adults and can cause progressive joint damage

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis: Classic for symmetric, erosive polyarthritis of MCP and PIP joints, with progressive joint deformity.

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma: Causes lytic lesions but not joint-centered erosive changes or deformity.

 

Option D. Reactive arthritis: Asymmetric and typically involves lower limb joints, usually not erosive or deforming in hands.

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Glucose

 

In pleural effusion fluid from a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), the following characteristics are typically found except high glucose.

 

  • Low glucose is characteristic, as glucose is consumed by inflammatory cells and bacteria in infected or inflammatory effusions; high glucose is not typical in RA pleural effusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RA factor: RA factor is often present in pleural fluid due to local immune activity.

 

Option B. Cholesterol crystals: Cholesterol crystals are a classic feature of RA pleural effusions, sometimes termed "pseudo-chylothorax".

 

Option D. High LDH: High LDH is typical, reflecting high inflammatory activity and cell turnover.

questions.text: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EGPA

 

The triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia is characteristic of Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA) (formerly Churg-Strauss syndrome).

 

  • EGPA is a small to medium vessel vasculitis associated with asthma, eosinophilia, cutaneous manifestations (such as palpable purpura), and neuropathy, specifically mononeuritis multiplex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis involves immune complex deposition, commonly with purpura and renal involvement but not eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa typically involves medium vessels with systemic symptoms, but eosinophilia is not a major feature.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis: Giant cell arteritis affects large vessels and presents with headache and visual symptoms rather than eosinophilia or mononeuritis multiplex.

questions.text: All the following conditions are manifestations of IgG4RD except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crescentic glomerulonephritis

 

IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD) is a fibroinflammatory condition characterized by tumefactive lesions, dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates rich in IgG4-positive plasma cells, and storiform fibrosis. 

 

Common manifestations include:

 

  • Autoimmune pancreatitis – pancreatic enlargement with obstructive jaundice.
  • Lymphoplasmacytic aortitis – thickening of the aortic wall.
  • Orbital pseudotumor – swelling of orbital tissues causing proptosis or diplopia.

 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis is usually immune-complex mediated (e.g., anti-GBM disease, ANCA vasculitis) and is not associated with IgG4-RD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune pancreatitis: Classic organ involvement in IgG4-RD.

 

Option C. Lymphoplasmacytic aortitis: IgG4-related large vessel inflammation.

 

Option D. Orbital pseudotumor: Common manifestation, often with lacrimal gland involvement.

questions.text: 35-year-old woman presents with fever and pain in knees and ankles. On exam, she has B/L parotid swelling, and she has lesion shown in the picture below. Laboratory studies are normal except for a slightly increased calcium level. What is the most appropriate Rx?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticosteroids

 

The most appropriate treatment is corticosteroids.

 

  • The image shows erythema nodosum—tender red nodules, primarily on the shins.
  • The case features: fever, migratory polyarthritis, bilateral parotid swelling, and mild hypercalcemia.
  • This constellation suggests sarcoidosis (classic Lofgren’s syndrome: erythema nodosum, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, fever, and arthritis).
  • First-line therapy for symptomatic sarcoidosis (especially with significant organ involvement) is corticosteroids to suppress inflammation and granuloma formation.

choices.text: Retinal imaging with optical coherence tomography (OCT)

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with severe headaches and sudden monocular vision loss has ESR of 67 mm/hr. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administration of oral corticosteroids

 

  • The patient presents with classic giant cell arteritis (GCA) features:
    • Age >50 years
    • New-onset headache
    • Sudden monocular vision loss
    • Elevated ESR (67 mm/hr)
  • Immediate treatment with corticosteroids is essential to prevent permanent vision loss, even before confirming the diagnosis with temporal artery biopsy.
  • Oral corticosteroids are appropriate if no severe visual loss or systemic symptoms; intravenous methylprednisolone may be used if vision loss is severe or rapidly progressing.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Temporal artery biopsy:
    • Necessary for definitive diagnosis, but should NOT delay corticosteroid treatment.
    • Ideally performed within 1–2 weeks of starting steroids.

 

  • Option C. Retinal imaging with OCT:
    • Can evaluate retinal changes, but does not treat or prevent further vision loss.

 

  • Option D. Brain MRI:
    • Usually normal in GCA; not required acutely.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with burning sensations and an irresistible urge to move her legs at night, relieved by movement. Which is the first-line drug that can be prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gabapentin

 

  • The patient has classic features of restless legs syndrome (RLS):
    • Burning/tingling in legs
    • Urge to move legs, worse at night
    • Symptoms relieved by movement
  • First-line pharmacologic treatment for moderate-to-severe RLS is Gabapentin or Gabapentin enacarbil, especially if painful sensations predominate.
  • Dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole) are also used but may cause augmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonazepam: A benzodiazepine; may improve sleep but not first-line for RLS.

 

Option C. Riluzole: Used in ALS; irrelevant for RLS.

 

Option D. Benztropine: Anticholinergic; used for Parkinson’s disease and drug-induced parkinsonism, not RLS.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs act on sodium channels and potentiate slow sodium inactivation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lacosamide

 

  • Lacosamide is an antiepileptic drug that enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, stabilizing hyperexcitable neuronal membranes and inhibiting repetitive firing.
  • Unique mechanism: selectively prolongs slow inactivation, unlike phenytoin or carbamazepine, which affect fast inactivation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Topiramate: 
    • Multiple mechanisms: enhances GABA-A activity, antagonizes AMPA/kainate receptors, inhibits carbonic anhydrase.
    • Does not specifically potentiate slow sodium inactivation.

 

  • Option C. Phenytoin: 
    • Prolongs fast inactivation of sodium channels, reducing repetitive firing.
    • Does not act on slow inactivation.

 

  • Option D. Lamotrigine: 
    • Inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels (fast inactivation) and blocks glutamate release.
    • Slow inactivation potentiation is minimal.

questions.text: A young woman, who is blind, presents with nighttime insomnia. What is the drug of choice for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tasimelteon

 

  • The patient is totally blind and experiences non-24-hour sleep-wake disorder, a common circadian rhythm sleep disorder in blind individuals.
  • Tasimelteon is a melatonin receptor agonist (MT1 and MT2) approved specifically for non-24-hour sleep-wake disorder.
  • It entrains the circadian rhythm in patients who lack light perception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zolpidem: Sedative-hypnotic (GABA-A modulator) for insomnia, but does not correct circadian misalignment.

 

Option B. Ramelteon: Melatonin receptor agonist, mainly for sleep-onset insomnia, not approved for non-24-hour sleep-wake disorder.

 

Option C. Agomelatine: Melatonin receptor agonist + 5-HT2C antagonist, used for depression with sleep disturbance, not for non-24-hour circadian rhythm disorder.

questions.text: A patient having persistent allergic rhinitis is on treatment with intranasal steroids. You wish to add an antihistamine to his treatment regimen. He requests an intranasal preparation. Which of the following will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Azelastine

 

  • The patient has persistent allergic rhinitis and is already on intranasal corticosteroids.
  • Azelastine is an intranasal H1-antihistamine, effective for nasal congestion, sneezing, itching, and rhinorrhea.
  • Adding azelastine provides local antihistaminic effect with minimal systemic absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebastine: Oral second-generation antihistamine; not available as intranasal.

 

Option B. Mizolastine: Oral antihistamine; no intranasal formulation.

 

Option D. Fexofenadine: Oral antihistamine; not used intranasally.

questions.text: Which is the monoclonal antibody approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sarilumab

 

  • Sarilumab is a human monoclonal antibody against the IL-6 receptor.
  • It is approved for moderate-to-severe rheumatoid arthritis in patients who have an inadequate response to conventional DMARDs.
  • IL-6 blockade reduces inflammation, joint damage, and systemic symptoms of RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: PD-1 inhibitor, used in cancer immunotherapy, not RA.

 

Option B. Durvalumab: PD-L1 inhibitor, used in oncology, not for RA.

 

Option D. Pembrolizumab: PD-1 inhibitor, also for cancer immunotherapy, not RA.

choices.text: Adjuvants are indicated only for mild pain

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the WHO analgesic ladder for chronic pain in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Step 3 includes use of Morphine

 

  • The WHO analgesic ladder is a three-step approach for managing chronic pain:
    1. Step 1: Non-opioids (e.g., paracetamol, NSAIDs) for mild pain.
    2. Step 2: Weak opioids (e.g., codeine, tramadol) ± non-opioids for moderate pain.
    3. Step 3: Strong opioids (e.g., morphine, fentanyl) ± non-opioids for severe pain.
  • Adjuvant drugs (antidepressants, anticonvulsants) can be added at any step depending on pain type.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous route is preferred: Oral route is preferred; IV is used only if oral administration is not possible.

 

Option C. Adjuvants are indicated only for mild pain: Adjuvants can be used at any step, particularly for neuropathic pain.

 

Option D. Analgesics are given "on demand": Analgesics should be given “by the clock” to maintain consistent pain control.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in diabetic neuropathy, post herpetic neuralgia and spinal cord injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pregabalin

 

  • Pregabalin is an anticonvulsant and neuropathic pain agent.
  • Mechanism: binds to α2δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, reducing excitatory neurotransmitter release.
  • Approved for diabetic neuropathy, postherpetic neuralgia, and neuropathic pain due to spinal cord injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: Effective for trigeminal neuralgia, but not first-line for diabetic neuropathy or postherpetic neuralgia.

 

Option C. Amitriptyline: A tricyclic antidepressant used for neuropathic pain, especially diabetic neuropathy, but less well tolerated; not first-line for spinal cord injury.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Primarily an anticonvulsant; rarely used for neuropathic pain.

questions.text: Which is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium valproate

 

  • Refractory or intractable rheumatic chorea occurs when first-line treatments (like haloperidol or benzodiazepines) fail.
  • Sodium valproate is effective in controlling chorea due to its GABAergic enhancement and stabilizing neuronal excitability.
  • It is particularly useful in severe, persistent, or refractory cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haloperidol: First-line for chorea, but may be ineffective or poorly tolerated in refractory cases.

 

Option C. Diazepam: Benzodiazepine; can reduce mild chorea or agitation, not ideal for refractory cases.

 

Option D. Probenecid: Uricosuric agent; not used for chorea.

questions.text: A 72-year-old right-handed male is brought to the emergency department by his daughter. According to her, he had only shaved the right half of his face this morning. The patient displays poor insight into this behavior, although there are no obvious deficits in comprehension, speech, and repetition. His past medical history includes hypertension, which is well controlled with labetalol. Physical exam suggests intact comprehension, speech, and repetition. Sensation is grossly intact bilaterally, with no focal motor deficits appreciated. However, when asked to draw a clock face, he omits the numbers 8, 9, 10, and 11. Which of the following vessels is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right middle cerebral artery

 

The patient’s presentation of hemispatial neglect (ignoring the left side of the body, shaving only the right half of the face), poor insight, intact comprehension, speech, and repetition, and left-sided visual neglect (omitting numbers 8-11 in clock drawing) suggests a lesion causing right parietal lobe dysfunction.

 

  • Hemispatial neglect is typically caused by a lesion in the right parietal lobe, which is supplied by the right middle cerebral artery (MCA).
  • Left MCA stroke usually causes aphasia or speech deficits due to involvement of the dominant hemisphere.
  • Left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) stroke affects leg motor/sensory function more than spatial awareness.
  • Left posterior cerebral artery affects occipital lobe (visual field defects but no neglect).
  • This patient’s neglect and unilateral inattention without language deficits points towards right MCA infarct.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female is brought to the emergency department due to progressive dyspnea and fatigue for the past two days. One week prior, she was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and subsequently treated with ciprofloxacin. She also reports a one-month history of intermittent fatigability that often worsens throughout the day and improves with rest. She denies fevers, weight loss, diarrhea, or sick contacts. Vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C (98.5°F), blood pressure of 140/88 mmHg, heart rate of 94 beats/min, and shallow respirations of 22 breaths/min. Oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally with accessory muscle use, and paradoxical abdominal wall motion is noted on inspiration. Achilles and patellar reflexes are 2+ bilaterally with decreased muscle strength in the upper and lower extremities. Arterial blood gas sampling is performed with the following results:

pH: 7.24

pCOz: 60 mmHg

pOz: 90 mmHg

Bicarbonate: 26 mEq/L

Based on this patient's presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myasthenic crisis

 

  • The patient has a history of intermittent fatigability that worsens during the day → classic myasthenia gravis pattern.
  • She now presents with acute respiratory failure (pH 7.24, pCO₂ 60 mmHg, shallow respirations, paradoxical abdominal motion) → myasthenic crisis.
  • Precipitating factor: Infection (UTI) or certain medications (ciprofloxacin) can trigger crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Guillain-Barré syndrome: Usually presents with ascending weakness, areflexia, and sensory changes. Reflexes are normal in this patient, making GBS less likely.

 

Option C. Polymyositis: Causes symmetric proximal muscle weakness but not fluctuating fatigability or rapid respiratory compromise.

 

Option D. Tetanus: Presents with muscle rigidity, spasms, and trismus, not fluctuating weakness with fatigability.

choices.text: Mutation of the LDLR gene on chromosome 19
One copy of the APOE E4 gene on chromosome 19
Two copies of the APOE E2 gene on chromosome 19

questions.text: A team of genetics researchers is working to develop a new gene therapy targeting the downstream effects of Alzheimer disease. They sought out and identified multiple candidate genes through genome-wide association studies. A complete meta-analysis of studies involving autosomal dominant inheritance patterns using linkage-based methodology was reviewed to isolate relatively large culprit regions on chromosomes. Over twenty-nine variants were found to provide a statistically significant effect for increasing the odds of removal of dysfunctional beta-amyloid plaques. Of these, the research team discovered one candidate gene variant, which provided a greater conferred risk for lifetime development of sporadic Alzheimer disease than all other candidate genes. Which of the following confers the most significant risk for the development of Alzheimer disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) One copy of the APOE E4 gene on chromosome 19

 

  • APOE (Apolipoprotein E) gene on chromosome 19 has three major alleles: E2, E3, and E4.
  • E4 allele is the strongest genetic risk factor for sporadic (late-onset) Alzheimer disease.
    • One copy of E4 increases risk 3–4 fold.
    • Two copies increase risk up to 12-fold.
  • It affects beta-amyloid clearance and contributes to plaque deposition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple trinucleotide repeats of CAG: Associated with Huntington disease, not Alzheimer disease.

 

Option B. Mutation of the LDLR gene on chromosome 19: Linked to familial hypercholesterolemia, not AD.

 

Option D. Two copies of the APOE E2 gene: E2 allele is protective, not a risk factor.
